awd_titl_txt: Educating Entrepreneurial Technicians for Unmanned Aerial Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) industry continues to grow at a rapid rate, creating new jobs and economic opportunities. As a result, there is a strong demand for technicians with knowledge about the technology, operation, and rules of UAS, as well as effective communication skills, business know-how, and the skills to safely and effectively apply the technologies for commercial purposes. Widespread commercial UAS activities in the United States have already increased workforce demands, not just in UAS companies but also across a broad range of industries that use UAS. Offering ways for students to obtain the skill sets to work in existing companies, develop their own businesses, or create their own inventions with UAS technologies is becoming increasingly important. To help address this need, Sinclair Community College and their industry partners will develop an education program that prepares the entrepreneurial technicians needed in the UAS field. In this way, the project will seek to enhance the number of well-qualified UAS technicians, thus supporting the continued growth and integration of UAS solutions for the nation's industries.

The goal of this project is to educate a new type of entrepreneurial technician who is equipped with the technical and other skills required for success in the dynamic, quickly evolving UAS industry. The project partners will develop a competency-based curriculum that results in a one-year UAS Entrepreneurship Certificate. This curriculum will include new courses that focus on entrepreneurial principles and modified existing courses that focus on UAS applications and technologies. Enhancements will include hands-on and interactive project-based learning experiences through which students can master UAS knowledge and skills.  An innovative aspect of the curriculum will be a UAS entrepreneurship kick-starter competition. This venture capital style competition will engage students in applying course content to create new ideas or new connections to available intellectual property. The competition will cultivate students' entrepreneurship abilities by providing them with access to mentoring from technical and business experts, as well as access to cutting-edge UAS technologies. The project team will also develop course modules on UAS technologies and entrepreneurial applications for high school teachers and students. These materials will be used in outreach and professional development activities with high schools to promote career interest in this technology field. Project materials and results will be widely shared and disseminated on websites of partnering organizations, in publications, through webinars, and presentations at regional and national venues. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The “Educating Entrepreneurial Technicians for Unmanned Aerial Systems” project had the overarching goal of developing a model to educate a new type of entrepreneurial Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) technician who will have the knowledge and skills to apply Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) technology and Intellectual Property (IP) in a variety of high-tech applications. The main objectives of the project were:

  1. Research, develop, and document new community college roles and programs designed to increase the number of entrepreneurial technicians using UAS and related technologies to expand established firms or launch successful high-tech business startups.
  2. Build new collaborations between academia, industry, and government to support technicians seeking venture capital funds and support services for startups using UAS and related technologies.
  3. Increase awareness regarding UAS and entrepreneurial ventures as viable technical career paths among college and high school faculty and students (particularly underrepresented populations).
  4. Actively engage other colleges and universities across the country in project dissemination activities.

Advancing these objectives, several major deliverables were completed, including:

  1. A competency model for the UAS Entrepreneur developed and validated by industry representatives, using a proven Developing A CUrriculuM (DACUM) process.
  2. Model processes for developing an entrepreneurial kick-starter program focused on UAS but more broadly applicable to other developing technical fields.
  3. Master syllabi and course descriptions for each course comprising the new one-year certificate.
  4. Modules and videos to support high school teacher professional development and career awareness.
  5. Model recruitment and retention plans to support the involvement of underrepresented populations.
  6. Presentations and technical or academic journal articles describing project activities and outcomes.

All project objectives and deliverables were met or exceeded, with notable highlights listed in the following categories:

UAS Entrepreneur STEM Materials
Five modules of STEM materials were developed focused on UAS entrepreneurship for use in high school classrooms and during camps. The content introduced UAS and related technologies, applications, business models, and elevator pitches, as well as provided an opportunity for students to develop their own concept into an elevator pitch presented to their class for peer and instructor rubric guided feedback. The materials include slide presentations, videos, rubrics, references, and other resources for teacher and student use. Several virtual training workshops were conducted to orient six teachers to the materials and assist in planning implementation in classrooms, which was completed by several teachers. Additionally, the materials were used in whole or part during several UAS focused summer camps conducted by Sinclair College, reaching 37 middle and high school students.

UAS Entrepreneur Business Plan Competition
Implementing guidance from project collaborators at the Entrepreneurs’ Center in Dayton, Ohio, a UAS business plan competition (BPC) model was developed that included application, elevator pitch, mentoring and business plan development, and final business plan submission and concept presentation phases. Sinclair College piloted the BPC in Ohio twice, with 13 participants in the initial competition and 12 participants in the second. The winner from both Sinclair executed competitions formed Limited Liability Corporations and received an award of support and consultative services valued at $25,000, with funds provided through the Ohio Entrepreneurial Service Provider (ESP) program as managed by the Entrepreneurs’ Center. Atlantic Cape Community College piloted the UAS BPC in New Jersey with nine participants and an overall winner selected. Northland Community and Technical College conducted a modified approach that implemented a three day Drone Entrepreneur Boot Camp in Minnesota drawing 12 participants. Their event included presentations by academic, industry, and government subject-matter experts prior to participant organization into groups on the final day to develop a business concept and pitch it to the audience. The participants from all competitions were drawn from diverse backgrounds, including the selection of a minority female as the second Ohio UAS business plan competition winner.

College Credit Curriculum
Leveraging inputs from subject-matter experts recorded through a project commissioned DACUM workshop, Sinclair College created a 33 semester hour One-Year UAS Entrepreneurship Certificate, which included 15 courses. Of those, two courses, AVT 1115: Introduction to UAS Entrepreneurship and AVT 2115: UAS Entrepreneurship Capstone, were developed from scratch, with others updated as needed to add program specific content. This certificate was developed with pathways to Sinclair’s existing UAS Associate and Bachelor of Applied Science degrees. The new courses were piloted during the project period and the new one-year certificate is available.

Distribution and Dissemination
Project developed STEM content was posted to the Dayton Regional STEM Center website for public access and the master syllabi for the One-Year UAS Entrepreneurship Certificate were posted to the Sinclair College website. As one of many public presentation and outreach activities, Sinclair College organized Unmanned Systems Academic Summits, which occurred three times over the project reaching a combined total of 11,012 with information about the project and developed resources, as well as other educational information salient to UAS entrepreneurship.


Last Modified: 01/24/2023
Modified by: Andrew D Shepherd
